title: Keith number
summary: In recreational mathematics, a Keith number or repfigit number (short for repetitive Fibonacci-like digit) is a natural number n {\displaystyle n} in a given number base b {\displaystyle b} with k {\displaystyle k} digits such that when a sequence is created such that the first k {\displaystyle k} terms are the k {\displaystyle k} digits of n {\displaystyle n} and each subsequent term is the sum of the previous k {\displaystyle k} terms, n {\displaystyle n} is part of the sequence. Keith numbers were introduced by Mike Keith in 1987.[1] They are computationally very challenging to find, with only about 100 known.
